text: Figma co-founder and CEO Dylan Field shares his vision for the future of AI, design and human creativity. He’s increasingly optimistic that innovation will “lower the floor and raise the ceiling” for what people can accomplish. An excellent South by interview with The Verge’s Nilay Patel.
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: Brilliant. Kudos to the folks at Heineken for putting this together. Reminds me of the excellent work StoryCorps is now doing with their One Small Step  program that helps set up 1:1 interviews between people with differing perspectives. cc: Dave I.
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: While the focus on AI interfaces of the future has typically been centered on the concept of Agents, arguably the most logical interface of all has been right in front of us all along: the browser. The Browser Company has been hard at work reimagaining what an AI capable browser can be, and just launched the first of many exciting innovations they will be releasing towards achieving their vision. Congrats to Josh Miller, Hursh Agrawal, and the incredibly talented team at The Browser Company on the launch of Arc Search and a new era of Smart Browsing.
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: According to Him For Her founder and CEO Jocelyn Mangan, solving for thought diversity in the boardroom isn’t a pipeline problem, it’s a network problem. In this video, Jocelyn explains why solving this issue is so important and can be accomplished within the next ten years.
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: Well articulated reminder from Adam Grant that compassion and empathy are not synonymous. Compassion = Empathy + Action.

text: Don't typically comment on quantifiable milestones here as they're all part of the process, but 1B members is worth making an exception for. Congrats to every member of the team who worked so hard to make this possible. The best is yet to come.

text: In 2015, had the great privilege of interviewing Matthieu Ricard. Was instantly brought back to the timeless wisdom and compassion he shared then in his most recent interview with the New York Times.

text:
Was recently reminded of the surprisingly prescient vision of the digital future portrayed in this series of AT&T commercials released in 1994: https://lnkd.in/d6cV-n3U. 

As futuristic as the innovations seemed when the ads were first released, many would go on to become mainstream within the next two decades. 

Have seen a number of videos in the last few years focusing on the specific application of new technologies, e.g., AR/VR, autonomous vehicles, drones/flying taxis, robotics, etc., and we're all familiar with classic sci-fi films focused on an increasingly AI driven future. 

However, curious if anyone has seen anything produced recently comparable to the AT&T ads depicting what a future leveraging all of these technologies might look like 20-30 years from now?
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: As editor of WIRED, Nicholas Thompson, was one of the clearest and most insightful thinkers I knew regarding the implications of newly introduced technologies. As CEO of The Atlantic, he's now in a position to help his team navigate and leverage those advances. Here's a recent note he shared with them on the rise of AI that can be more broadly applied to others in the process of developing their approach.
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: Dave and the StoryCorps team have been building on this work to enable individuals to tell their stories and facilitate connections between people with different perspectives for years. Great to see this kind of well-deserved spotlight on such an important effort.

text:
What a great article — well worth the time to read. Love the clarity Shaquille O'Neal applies to the brands and businesses he gets involved with, all derived from his sense of personal connection, value and fun. Clear demonstration of the power of authenticity as a leader, entrepreneur and an investor. 

Daniel Roth and Ryan Roslansky, how about an interview on “The Path”?!
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text:
Over an Internet career spanning nearly three decades, I've seen the introduction of digital applications that marked at least two key inflection points for the industry as well as society more broadly.

In 1993, Mosaic launched its browser, providing an interface that enabled everyday users to consume digitized content. The rise of the consumer web followed and nothing would be the same.

Between 2003 and 2005, Digg, Delicious, Flickr, and YouTube introduced applications that enabled everyday users to share digitized links, images, and videos. The rise of social media platforms followed and nothing would be the same.

With recent innovations in AI, it appears we're now on the cusp of a third inflection point.

In 2022, Open AI introduced DALL-E 2, enabling everyday users to harness the power of AI to generate images.

The rise of AI is certainly not a new theme. It's been the subject of science fiction for decades, and over the last few years, understanding its implications and investing in its application have ranked among the top priorities for many companies in Tech and beyond.

This intense scrutiny on AI is why I've been struck by how surprised some of the industry's top technologists, executives, and investors have been over recent advances in the state of the art and its growing accessibility -- GPT 1, 2, 3, Dall-E 2, and Stable Diffusion just to name a few.

What's even more stunning is the stuff that hasn't launched yet, but soon will. The rise of AI generated text, images, audio and video will follow and nothing will be the same.

If you thought the consumer web and social media were disruptive, you ain't seen nothing yet.
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: Excellent interview with two of the most inspiring leaders I have the privilege of working with — Wemimo Abbey and Samir Goel. Here’s a brief excerpt in which they describe the talent they are looking for at Esusu:  “We’re doubling down on folks we call justice capitalists — people who have a head for business and a heart for the world. These people fundamentally believe that doing good and doing well are by no means mutually exclusive.”
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: Congratulations Esusu and Fannie Mae, on this industry transforming collaboration to create a more equitable housing market. Esusu continues to exemplify that doing well and doing good are not mutually exclusive. Well done, Wemimo Abbey  Samir Goel  and the Esusu team!
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: A stunning example of compassionate capitalism. Patagonia has always been a leader of this movement, but this takes it to another level. Hopefully, just the beginning and a model to be followed in the future.
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text:
Congrats, Dylan! It's nothing short of extraordinary to see what you and the team have accomplished over the last ten years. 

From the moment you started as a LinkedIn intern and conceived of the idea for LinkedIn for Good, it was clear you were an unusual talent (shout out to Tim O'Reilly and DJ Patil for recognizing your ability so early on). As much as we were hoping you'd join the company post-graduation, we all knew you were destined to be a game-changing entrepreneur. 

Unsurprisingly, over the last decade of working together, you have set the bar in terms of defining the kind of visionary founder, world-class executive, and industry transforming start-up I aspire to support as an investor and coach. Thank you, Dylan. Couldn't be more excited to watch where you take the company and what you accomplish from here!
subtitle: Executive Chairman at LinkedIn / Founding Partner Next Play Ventures

text: One of the most eloquent and insightful metaphors for teamwork I’ve heard, from jazz great Wynton Marsalis.

text: Nice to see this important distinction gaining more traction: Empathy is not an end game but rather a means towards a more compassionate outcome. Put another way: Compassion = Empathy + Action
